title: Does suffering give meaning to life in some way or another? - Quora

response.answer_text: Lemme add to Anonymous's answer. That yes, people who have nothing tend to appreciate more what they have. Heck, why do we even bother to eat? Because hunger makes us suffer. People who have survived are sometimes more grateful to be alive. But that also takes another aspect. The death of others. How sometimes one is grateful that one survived, one was fortunate, while others weren't. Someone can appreciate what they have, considering there are other people who don't. Children in Africa could've eaten that food you wasted. Man, isn't that one most of us heard from our mothers at one point on life, or many times... But it adds even more meaning to life. Through empathy. Because the suffering of others gives us the opportunity to open our hearts and do what we can to help. Bringing people closer together. So, yes, we might hate suffering, or at least I do, but cannot deny that it adds a lot of meaning/point/value, to life. That is why it has to exist. That is why when we are in Heaven, we will appreciate Heaven, because we have known suffering, which was part of God's plan since the beginning.

Let's be very clear. We are not talking of children that undergo suffering. Presuming that we are speaking of suffering as an adult, this is what I think of it. If at all anything, suffering brings a delusion of meaning to life. When I say suffering, I do not mean going through difficult times, going through pain, being wronged. I mean suffering in itself, as an action, as a consequence of what has happened to you. When indulged in without reflection, suffering can create a sense of false self-importance. It can lead us into a cycle of blame, a negative narrative. It can lead us to create false battles within and without that distract us from discovering the real purpose of our lives that stems out of our inner vitality. Author Haruki Murakami once quoted in his book “Pain is inevitable, but suffering is optional.” If applied mindfully, suffering could potentially bring us to our inner light. But when suffering becomes the narrative of our lives, we are no longer able to access our true potential to realisation.

I’ve noticed that much of our conversation is about how great things are (great vacation, great movie, great restaurant, etc). It’s also saturated with complaints about how bad things are. I find myself telling stories about myself, my life and the suffering I endured, and listening to others do the same. Everything we do, we do for the rewarding feeling it brings, including telling stories of great stuff and miserable stuff. We are story tellers first and foremost. Suffering does nothing but make us suffer; in the telling, we find meaning.

A span of tough time spent either depressed or reeling from a loss is something that a lot of us don’t want nor so we wish upon those we care about. It is natural to be afraid of suffering for it’s not a desirable state of existence. One must however, learn how to cope with it. At one such point of time in my life my mom told me that “success is the best revenge”. At that time I didn’t know what it meant or implied. Over a couple of months I got better and eventually completed my studies and gave my examinations. I did well, and I was happy. In a way the experience milder me because now when I look back, I can see that I evolved and that I had the strength to do so, which I might not have gotten without suffering.

We give meaning to life, and so we can give meaning to our suffering in a variety of ways, many of which are already mentioned here. I’d only like to add that I think that there’s something to be said for the notion that ‘we choose our pain’. In a certain sense, we are defined by the things that cause suffering. One may choose to remember a painful event because of the lessons that can be learned thereby. One may define herself by feeling sympathy and pity for those less fortunate. One may practice meditation in an attempt to alleviate or avoid suffering. In each case, suffering seems to give life some meaning.

It depends. I suffered as a child. It made me thoughtful and protective of the rights of others. Another person, in the same situation and with the same personality, would have been wounded beyond repair. There are similar distinctions in other conditions. Poverty forced on others can lead to wasted lives and sickness and death. But someone who takes poverty on himself or herself, and grows through it, is among the most blessed of people.

Yes Surely. Many new inventions in science and systems in society have come out from sufferings. One needs to analyse the sufferings and look for solution. Whenever there is suffering, see that the solution is near. For example, when it is 5 o clock in the morning, we look forward to sunrise and it happens. When suffering, imagine it is 5 o clock and Sun is rising now..

No, there’s no meaning in suffering. It is wired in our heads, that everything worthwhile, shouldn’t come easy. BUT, look at Your own experience, and You will see, that best things in life came completely free of charge and by itself. Suffering only brings more suffering, but not more meaning. Joy on the other hand, brings more joy, and when You are joyful, You are automatically interested in others to share it, and that’s how You CREATE a meaning.

The short answer is that it defines relationships to specific life events and significant people. Rather you relate to the pain or the lessons learned from these events and relationships is your choice. Their is commonality in coping with suffering that helps us understand and have empathy and caring for others and ourselves. The amount of and nature a persons meaning is unique to each person.
I suspect the answer would change what religion (if any) you subscribe to. Those who believe in an afterlife affected by the current life try to find meaning in suffering.
Yes, that’s simple. Suffering is in your life for one reason and one reason only, for you to discover who you truly are.
